thread.title: Kim Jong-un’s regime close to COLLAPSE as China 'moves troops to North Korean border'
thread.title_full: Kim Jong-un’s regime close to COLLAPSE as China 'moves troops to North Korean border'

title: Kim Jong-un’s regime close to COLLAPSE as China 'moves troops to North Korean border'
text:
GETTY COLLAPSE: China closes in on the Hermit Kingdom as Kim faces multiple threats 
The Hermit Kingdom is reportedly close to collapse as China appears to have finally lost patience with its Communist neighbour. 
The murder of Kim Jong-nam – half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un – appears to have led to divines within the paranoid regime. 
And now China – one of North Korea’s last allies – has moved 1,000 troops to the border . Real or fake? The North Korea tyrant Kim Jong-un WANTS the West to see Thursday, 16th February 2017 As innocent people starve in gulags, Kim Jong-un allows tightly controlled press trips to show a version of North Korea most citizens wouldn't even recognise. Happy, prosperous, developed: check out these pictures and see 1 / 34 A man smokes a cigarette in a bar “The Chinese military will take the necessary measures, ” Ren Guoqiang 
The deployment is meant to stop an influx of refugees from North Korea if the state crumbles. 
Beijing suspended imports of coal from North Korea after its recent missile launch – depriving them a crucial source of capital. 
China defence ministry spokesman Ren Guoqiang said China would maintain its usual policy towards Pyongyang, and denied they were sending troops. 
He added: "The Chinese military will take the necessary measures, according to the need that arises in the security environment, to safeguard national security and sovereignty. 
"We are resolute in safeguarding the peace and security of the Korean Peninsula, sticking to the objective of denuclearisation and to resolving disputes through dialogue and consultation." Inside North Korea: The pictures Kim Jong-un doesn't want you to see Tuesday, 13th December 2016 Since 2008, photographer Eric Lafforgue ventured to North Korea six times. Thanks to digital memory cards, he was able to save photos that was forbidden to take inside the segregated state 1 / 62 Eric Lafforgue/Exclusivepix Medi Taking pictures in the DMZ is easy, but if you come too close to the soldiers, they stop you 
The anti-ballistic device could shoot down any nuclear device fired from the hermit state. 
But Ren argued that the system could be used to spy on Chinese missile flights. Related articles
